While QQQM is newer and less liquid, its cost savings over time make it an attractive option for buy-and-hold investors seeking exposure to the Nasdaq-100 Index. The Nasdaq-100 Index has consistently outperformed other benchmarks, making both ETFs appealing for growth-oriented portfolios.

title: MicroSectors™ Launches FANG & Innovation ETNs, 'BULZ' & 'BERZ'
summary: REX Shares, LLC announced the launch of two new MicroSectors Exchange Traded Notes (ETNs), BULZ and BERZ, issued by the Bank of Montreal. These ETNs are linked to the Solactive FANG Innovation Index, which tracks major U.S.-listed tech and internet/media companies. The products aim to offer sophisticated investors leveraged and inverse leveraged exposure to prominent technology and innovation stocks.

title: The Digital Pulse: Outbrain, GearBrain's Content Recommendation Engine of Choice
summary: GearBrain introduces "The Digital Pulse," a new monthly feature focusing on digital trends, with its inaugural column highlighting Outbrain Inc. (OB). The article explains why GearBrain chose Outbrain as its content recommendation engine, citing better quality recommendations, higher revenue generation, and minimal impact on user experience and site speed compared to competitors like Taboola (TBLA). GearBrain emphasizes that revenue from Outbrain helps cover editorial costs while ensuring a positive user experience.

title: Procter & Gamble regains its title as top global advertiser
summary: Procter & Gamble has reclaimed its position as the world's top advertiser, surpassing Amazon, with a marketing expenditure of $11.5 billion in its last fiscal year. This resurgence highlights the CPG giant's strategy of maintaining ad spending even during difficult economic times, a move that brand consultants argue has consistently benefited the company. While Amazon has the capacity to increase its ad spending significantly, P&G's continued investment in marketing has proven effective in sustaining its brand presence and sales growth.

title: Microsoft Partnership Puts the 'S' & 'G' Into the 'E' in ESG
summary: Microsoft has partnered with Volt Energy to bring carbon-neutral electricity to underserved communities, addressing both environmental and social justice issues within the ESG framework. This initiative, while small in scale regarding initial power purchase, is seen as a significant step in pushing the boundaries of corporate environmental and social leadership. The article also highlights the Putnam Sustainable Leaders ETF (PLDR), which invests in companies like Microsoft that demonstrate proactive leadership in ESG issues and includes Microsoft as a top holding.

title: Board of Directors
summary: This article lists the members of the Joby Aviation Board of Directors, detailing their professional backgrounds and expertise. Each board member's biography highlights their relevant experience, particularly in technology, aviation, finance, and large-scale operations, which are valuable to Joby Aviation's mission. The board includes founders, seasoned executives from major tech and aviation companies, and finance professionals instrumental in the company's growth.

title: Oracle MySQL champion Nipun Agarwal explains the challenges of scaling up algorithms for data migrations
summary: Oracle's Nipun Agarwal discusses the challenges and enhancements of MySQL HeatWave, particularly its ability to scale algorithms for data migrations. Oracle has seen significant migrations to HeatWave from other cloud vendors, including AWS Aurora and Amazon RDS, driven by customer requests for more automation and greater scale in data analytics, leading to significant performance improvements and cost reductions. The company has also published benchmark data and scripts for competitors and customers to verify HeatWave's superior performance.

title: Kroger kicks off pickup partnership with Google
summary: Kroger has partnered with Google to integrate pickup service functionality into Google Maps for 96 stores across Ohio, Kentucky, and Indiana, with plans for further expansion. This allows shoppers to manage their orders, receive reminders, and notify stores of their arrival directly through the app. The initiative aims to enhance convenience, attract new shoppers, and capitalize on the surge in online grocery demand driven by the pandemic and the spread of the delta variant.

title: Procter & Gamble set to dethrone Amazon as world’s biggest advertiser
summary: Procter & Gamble is projected to surpass Amazon as the world's largest advertiser. This report from Ad Age Datacenter indicates a significant shift in global advertising spending.

title: Expedia Group pushes back its full return to the office to January 2022
summary: Expedia Group has announced a delay in its full return to office plans, now targeting January 2022 for a hybrid model due to evolving COVID-19 circumstances. This decision follows similar moves by other major tech companies like Amazon, Microsoft, Google, and Apple. The company's U.S. offices are open to vaccinated employees and visitors in the interim, with a global evaluation for similar approaches.

title: Online Shopping Just Got Cheesier: Cheez-It® Debuts First Ever Online Store With An Exclusive New Flavor Drop
summary: Cheez-It has launched its first-ever online store, CheezItHQ.com, offering exclusive products, merchandise, and limited-edition flavors. To celebrate, the brand is releasing a Cheez-It Extra Toasty Superfan 4-Pack featuring three new "Extra Toasty" variations. The new direct-to-consumer platform aims to connect with fans and bring food innovations to market faster.

title: GE Healthcare Brings Radiology Without Walls to Resource-Constrained Small Imaging Centers With AI-Enabled, Cloud Imaging Solution
summary: GE Healthcare has launched Edison True PACS, an AI-enabled, cloud-based Picture Archive and Communication System designed to help resource-constrained small imaging centers and community hospitals improve efficiency and diagnostic precision. This solution addresses challenges like radiologist shortages and IT resource limitations, offering remote reading capabilities and seamless integration of AI algorithms. It is available as a SaaS or on-premise offering with flexible subscription models to match varying organizational needs and budgets.

title: ServiceNow Acquires Database Performance Software Company Swarm64 -
summary: ServiceNow has acquired Swarm64, a Berlin-based database performance software company, to enhance its ability to scale digital workflows and handle growing data volumes for customers. Swarm64, founded in 2013 and previously venture-backed by Intel Capital and Xilinx, specializes in combining analytics and transactional database functionality. This acquisition aligns with ServiceNow's broader strategy of evolving its offerings beyond IT service management and expanding its partner ecosystem.

title: QQQ Versus QQQJ: Who’s Winning the Battle?
summary: This article compares the performance of the Invesco QQQ Trust (QQQ) and the Invesco NASDAQ Next Gen 100 ETF (QQQJ). QQQ, which focuses on large-cap tech companies, has outperformed QQQJ, a mid-cap focused ETF, across various timeframes. Chad Morganlander of Washington Crossing Advisors favors QQQ due to its higher quality large-cap names and stronger balance sheets.

title: Coronavirus: Starbucks, McDonald’s, Home Depot to require workers wear masks inside all locations
summary: Starbucks, McDonald’s, and Home Depot are reinstating indoor mask mandates for their employees due to the surge in COVID-19 infections caused by the delta variant. McDonald's and Target will specifically enforce these measures in high-risk transmission areas as identified by the CDC. These policy changes align with the CDC's updated recommendations urging vaccinated individuals to resume wearing masks indoors in certain settings.

title: FedEx plans to hire 3,000 in Memphis, 80,000 nationwide
summary: FedEx Corp. plans to hire 80,000 people nationwide, including 3,000 in Memphis, due to increased demand for residential delivery services driven by the e-commerce boom. The hiring initiative aims to address the rising need for its services across its various subsidiaries. This massive recruitment effort reflects the ongoing impact of e-commerce on the delivery industry.

title: Baxter Begins Collaboration with Amazon Web Services
summary: Baxter International Inc. is accelerating its digital transformation by collaborating with Amazon Web Services (AWS) across digital health solutions, customer experience, and technology modernization. This multi-year strategic agreement focuses on leveraging cloud technology to personalize patient care, enhance customer experiences, and modernize business processes, building on their existing work of migrating Baxter's data centers to the cloud. The transformation has already enabled advancements in home dialysis patient management with Sharesource and pharmacy workflow with DoseEdge, while also improving supply chain resilience during the pandemic.

title: Amazon and Best Buy Introduce New Insignia F50 Series Fire TVs
summary: Amazon and Best Buy announced a new lineup of Best Buy Insignia F50 Series Fire TVs, marking an expansion of their three-year strategic collaboration. These new TVs feature enhanced 4K Ultra HD resolution with quantum dot technology, Dolby Vision HDR, DTS Virtual-X sound, and integrated Alexa voice controls for an immersive entertainment experience. The companies also highlighted the success of their in-store pick-up option for Fire TVs, allowing customers to order on Amazon.com and pick up at Best Buy stores.

title: Deal Of The Century: How Michael Dell Turned His Declining PC Business Into A $40 Billion Windfall
summary: Michael Dell orchestrated a massive comeback for his company, Dell Technologies, transforming it from a declining PC business into an IT infrastructure giant with a $40 billion windfall for investors and a personal net worth of $50 billion. Through strategic leveraged buyouts, including taking the company private in 2013 and acquiring EMC in 2016, Dell successfully pivoted towards data center infrastructure, cloud management services, and the "edge" market. His financial engineering acumen and willingness to take on debt, combined with a correct reading of technology industry trends, allowed him to reassemble his empire and spin off VMware, solidifying his position in enterprise technology.

title: AT&T's DirecTV to become standalone video business
summary: AT&T Inc.'s satellite television provider, DirecTV, will become a standalone video business as part of a deal with buyout firm TPG Capital. The new entity will launch DirecTv Stream, a platform providing access to various streaming services. AT&T will retain a 70% ownership stake, while TPG Capital will own 30% of the new company, which was valued significantly lower than AT&T's initial purchase price.

title: Amazon to add delivery fee for Prime members who shop at Whole Foods
summary: Amazon is introducing a $9.95 delivery fee for Prime members shopping at Whole Foods Markets in several U.S. cities, effective August 30. This move indicates challenges in grocery delivery economics, even for large retailers, and is described as a pilot program to cover operating costs rather than raising food prices. Grocery pickup will remain free for Prime members.

title: Google’s upcoming plans for Israel: a server farm and fiber optics network
summary: Google is significantly expanding its operations in Israel following being awarded a government tender for cloud computing. This expansion includes establishing a server farm in the Sharon region and rolling out an ultra-high-speed fiber optics network, complementing its existing subsea cables. These investments aim to ensure maximum availability of Google's services, improve local internet infrastructure, and enhance Google's presence as a global telecommunications provider.

title: PepsiCo
summary: This article provides a corporate profile of PepsiCo, a global leader in the food and beverage industry. It highlights the company's history, leadership, global operations, commitment to sustainability, and extensive product range. The article also lists various related content covering PepsiCo's supply chain efficiency, sustainability efforts, and innovations within the industry.

title: Klarna acquires platform that connects content creators, retailers
summary: Klarna announced its acquisition of Apprl, a platform connecting content creators and retailers, to expand its retail marketing services. This move allows Klarna's partners to collaborate with creators on shoppable content and measure campaign results, aiming to enrich the shopping experience and accelerate retailer growth. The acquisition follows other strategic moves by Klarna, highlighting its entry into social commerce alongside other major companies.

title: Google founders have sold $1 billion in stock since May, the most since 2017
summary: Google co-founders Larry Page and Sergey Brin have sold over $1 billion worth of stock combined since May 2021, marking their first sales since 2017. Their stock sales, totaling more than $1.07 billion, occurred after the company's share price nearly tripled and Alphabet reported strong second-quarter earnings. Despite stepping down from executive roles in 2019, Page and Brin remain board members and control a majority of Alphabet's voting shares.

title: Vittorio Cretella left school at 17 to join the Italian Army. Now he’s CIO at Procter & Gamble.
summary: Vittorio Cretella, CIO of Procter & Gamble, discusses his unconventional career path from the Italian Army to leading digital transformation at the $300+ billion CPG company. He emphasizes the importance of diversity and inclusion in hiring, along with the pervasive role of digital transformation, machine learning, and cloud adoption in P&G's strategy. Cretella also highlights his work with NPower, a non-profit helping veterans and underserved youth find careers in tech, and P&G's neurodiversity hiring program.

title: Pitney Bowes Names Nick Smith SVP Strategy, Product & Platform Management, Global Ecommerce; Taps Amazon Veteran Brent Cervenka to Lead Global Ecommerce Operations
summary: Pitney Bowes Inc. (NYSE: PBI) has announced key leadership appointments in its Global Ecommerce division to strengthen its team ahead of the 2021 peak shipping season. Nick Smith has been named SVP Strategy, Product and Platform Management, Global Ecommerce, while Amazon veteran Brent Cervenka joins as SVP, Global Operations for Global Ecommerce. These appointments are part of a broader effort to recruit top talent and enhance the company's ecommerce logistics capabilities.

title: Kroger Unveils the Future of Grocery in Florida
summary: Kroger has opened a new robotic fulfillment center in Groveland, Florida, marking its significant expansion into the Florida market without traditional stores. This 375,000-sq.-ft. facility, operational since March, is exceeding expectations and is part of Kroger's strategy to double its online business by 2023. The center utilizes advanced technology from Ocado and serves as a hub in a spoke model aimed at eventually covering all of South Florida.

title: Traeger, Weber battle it out in barbecue IPO mini-boom as consumers spend billions on outdoor cooking
summary: The pandemic-driven surge in at-home grilling has led to a mini-boom in barbecue company IPOs, with Traeger and Weber leading the charge. Traeger priced its IPO at $18, valuing it at $2 billion, while rival Weber is also planning to go public with an expected valuation between $4 billion and $6 billion. Other companies like BBQGuys are also entering the public market, capitalizing on consumers spending billions on outdoor cooking equipment.

title: Microsoft acquires Seattle startup Suplari, which uses AI to analyze corporate spending
summary: Microsoft has acquired Suplari, a Seattle-based startup that leverages artificial intelligence to help companies analyze and manage corporate spending effectively. Suplari's technology provides recommendations for cost savings and risk exposure by analyzing procurement and spending data, which Microsoft plans to integrate with its Dynamics 365 offering. This acquisition highlights the growing trend of using AI and machine learning to automate data-intensive financial processes.

title: Amazon denies accepting Bitcoin, sends it tumbling
summary: Amazon.com Inc denied a media report suggesting it would accept Bitcoin payments by year-end, causing the cryptocurrency to tumble below $37,000. Earlier speculation, fueled by a job posting for a digital currency lead, had driven Bitcoin past $40,000. The company stated that while interested in the space, the specific plans for cryptocurrencies were not true.

title: Sparkline Launches Intangible Value ETF, ‘ITAN’
summary: Sparkline Capital has launched the Sparkline Intangible Value ETF (ITAN), an actively managed fund that evaluates companies based on their "intangible value." This value is derived from four pillars: intellectual property, brand equity, human capital, and network effects, integrated with tangible assets using machine learning. The fund aims to provide a modern interpretation of value investing by focusing on high-quality companies with strong intangible drivers of growth.

title: Intel to build Qualcomm chips, aims to catch foundry rivals by 2025
summary: Intel announced its factories will begin building chips for Qualcomm and Amazon, aiming to regain its leadership in chip manufacturing by 2025 against rivals like TSMC and Samsung. The company outlined a new roadmap with five chipmaking technologies and a revised naming scheme to reflect its competitive standing. This move signifies Intel's commitment to overcoming past delays and establishing itself as a leading foundry.

title: Tobi Lutke becomes Canada’s wealthiest company founder as Shopify shares soar
summary: Tobi Lutke, founder and CEO of Shopify Inc., has become Canada's wealthiest company founder as his stake in the e-commerce software provider reached US$13.3-billion. This surge in wealth is attributed to Shopify's stock crossing the $2,000 mark on the Toronto Stock Exchange and increasing optimism surrounding the company's second-quarter earnings. Analysts have raised their price targets for Shopify, anticipating its revenue to surpass US$1-billion for the first time in the June 30 quarter.

title: Better Buy: Invesco QQQ or Fidelity MSCI IT Index ETF
summary: This article compares the Invesco QQQ and Fidelity MSCI IT Index ETF, both strong technology-focused ETFs. While QQQ tracks the Nasdaq 100 and holds diverse sectors, the Fidelity ETF is a pure-play IT fund with broader diversification within the tech sector. The author concludes that the Fidelity ETF is the better buy due to its higher historical returns, lower expense ratio, and more consistent performance.

title: Young Indian investors warming up to clean energy ETFs: Report
summary: A report by Globalise indicates that young Indian investors are increasingly interested in clean energy ETFs, alongside growth-oriented technology funds. The ARK Innovation ETF, Renaissance IPO ETF, Small Cap Growth Vanguard ETF, Invesco WilderHill Clean Energy ETF, and Invesco QQQ Trust Series 1 were among the top ETFs in demand. Young investors, particularly from states like Tamil Nadu, Maharashtra, Delhi, and Karnataka, are seeking to diversify their portfolios through global investing platforms.

title: Rackspace Layoffs, Offshore Strategy Buried in 'Growth' Announcement -
summary: Rackspace Technology announced plans to invest up to $75 million in growth, while simultaneously conducting layoffs affecting 10% of its workforce and shifting job responsibilities offshore. The company's press release focused on growth and financial guidance, but an SEC filing revealed the "termination" of employees and the backfilling of roles in offshore service centers. This led to criticism of Rackspace's "overly ambitious PR spin" for obscuring the job cuts despite increasing financial forecasts.

title: Common Expands Washington, DC Co-Living Presence
summary: Common has expanded its co-living presence in Washington, D.C., securing its first management assignment in the National Landing submarket at 2221 S. Clark St. JBG SMITH selected Common to manage the co-living units and studios of the 216-unit community. This addition brings Common's total operations in Washington, D.C. to nine properties, further growing its portfolio through new management agreements and acquisitions in other major cities.

title: Editor’s Choice: Globalstar SPOT Gen4 satellite tracker
summary: The Globalstar SPOT Gen4 satellite tracker is a rugged, off-grid device designed for safety in remote areas, succeeding the Gen3 model with minor updates like improved waterproofing and mapping software. It offers SOS, tracking, and messaging functions via satellite, requiring a monthly plan starting at £10, and is particularly useful for bluewater cruising or venturing beyond mobile phone signal range. The device has a 4/5 MBY rating and is considered an affordable safety net for boaters.

title: The Mercedes-Benz Superdome is Renamed Caesars Superdome
summary: The historic Mercedes-Benz Superdome has officially been renamed the Caesars Superdome after Louisiana lawmakers approved a 10-year, $138 million naming rights deal with Caesars Entertainment. This renaming follows a long process that included the New Orleans Saints hiring Oak View Group to secure a new naming sponsor and is part of a larger $450 million renovation project aimed at modernizing the facility and keeping the Saints in Louisiana until 2035.

title: Worldwide internet outages: Major apps including Amazon, HBO Max, Airbnb down
summary: A worldwide internet outage affected numerous major apps and websites, including Amazon, HBO Max, Airbnb, FedEx, and Delta Airlines. Akamai Technologies, a global content delivery network, confirmed a service disruption that caused the widespread issues. The company later implemented a fix, and services began resuming normal operations.

title: How an Investor Helped Netflix Disclose Its ESG Performance
summary: Individual investor Lily Bowles successfully prompted Netflix to disclose its material ESG performance through a shareholder resolution, which she later withdrew after the company demonstrated willingness to comply. Her experience highlights how difficult it is for individual investors to engage with companies, especially with new SEC restrictions that make such efforts harder to replicate despite the potential for positive change. The article also discusses the potential for rule changes under the new SEC chairperson to mitigate these challenges.

title: Cox Media Group Makes Deal With Amazon Advertising
summary: Cox Media Group (CMG) has partnered with Amazon Advertising, allowing local advertisers working with CMG Local Solutions to buy and analyze display and over-the-top ads through the Amazon demand-side platform. This collaboration aims to provide local businesses with enhanced tools and expertise to achieve their marketing goals more effectively, building on a similar arrangement Amazon made with E.W. Scripps.

title: Microsoft acquires security start-up CloudKnox
summary: Microsoft announced its acquisition of CloudKnox, a security start-up that develops software to help companies manage and reduce access permissions to their cloud resources. This acquisition is part of Microsoft's broader strategy to expand its security business, which has seen over $10 billion in revenue in the prior 12 months. CloudKnox's software functions across Microsoft Azure, Amazon, and Google public clouds, identifying and removing unused permissions and flagging unusual activity to prevent security breaches.

title: Opioid maker J&J, distributors near $26B deal with US states
summary: Johnson & Johnson and three major drug distributors are finalizing a $26 billion settlement to resolve thousands of opioid-related lawsuits across the US. The deal involves McKesson Corp, Cardinal Health Inc, AmerisourceBergen Corp paying $21 billion and J&J contributing $5 billion. States have the option to accept the full settlement or parts of it, with bonuses for broader local government participation.

title: The Best Wireless Home Security Systems Are Easier to Set Up Than You Think
summary: This article reviews five top wireless home security systems, highlighting their ease of setup and key features. It provides recommendations for different needs and budgets, from the top pick Ring Alarm Home Security System to budget-friendly options and systems for subscription-averse buyers. The article also discusses important considerations like the number of sensors and cameras needed, expansion options, and monthly service fees.

title: Capital One Steps Up Hiring Software Engineers After Cloud Migration
summary: Capital One is significantly increasing its hiring of software engineers, aiming to add over 3,000 technologists by the end of the year. This hiring surge is partly attributed to the bank's migration to Amazon's public cloud, which is being used as a recruitment incentive for new employees. Mike Eason, SVP of engineering at Capital One, notes that engineers are drawn to working in cloud environments.

title: Focus: Getting the cap on the bottle: Inside P&G's robot ambitions
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) is using advanced robotics and automation to maintain its competitive edge in the consumer goods market by reducing manufacturing costs and improving efficiency. Despite being known for branding, P&G develops its own automation solutions, focusing on tasks like precise packaging and handling diverse product shapes. This push for automation is also driven by the need for social distancing during the pandemic and labor shortages, with P&G continuously exploring new robotic applications for its factories.

title: The Zoom-Five9 deal is a big bet for the video conferencing company
summary: Zoom has announced its intent to acquire Five9 for $14.7 billion, representing nearly 15% of Zoom's market capitalization. This acquisition is seen as a significant bet for Zoom to expand its offerings beyond video conferencing and tap into Five9's customer base, despite Five9's slower revenue growth compared to Zoom's core business. The deal aims to enhance total addressable market and create accretive value for both companies.

title: What became of 2020's biggest US tech IPOs?
summary: This article reviews the performance of the three biggest US tech IPOs of 2020 (Snowflake, DoorDash, and Airbnb) since their public debuts. It details their IPO specifics, what they do, and their stock performance up to July 16, 2021, highlighting their initial surges and subsequent fluctuations. The article also touches upon the upcoming tech IPOs in India and other significant tech-related news from the week.

title: Putting the ‘Q’ in NASDAQ: Quantum Computing Inc. Lists on Nasdaq Capital Market
summary: Quantum Computing Inc. (QCI) has announced its listing on the Nasdaq Capital Market, with common stock trading under the symbol QUBT set to commence on July 15, 2021. QCI aims to democratize quantum computing with its Qatalyst™ software, enabling businesses to solve complex problems without extensive quantum programming expertise. This Nasdaq listing is expected to boost QCI's profile, liquidity, and shareholder value in the investment community.

title: The Costs of Digitizing Education
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic highlighted the costs and challenges of digitizing education, revealing dissatisfaction with online learning outcomes and increased expenses. However, the author argues for a broader perspective, suggesting that technology can improve both educational outcomes and economics by addressing systematic issues in traditional education. Companies like John Wiley & Sons, New Oriental Education, Pearson, and TAL Education are positioned to capitalize on these trends through credentialing, online programs, and innovative content delivery models.

title: Target's teacher discount is coming back. Here's how educators, including home school teachers can save 15%
summary: Target is bringing back its 15% back-to-school teacher discount for two weeks, running from July 18 to July 31. This discount is available to various educators, including K-12, homeschool, preschool teachers, and university professors, who verify their eligibility through the Target Circle loyalty program. Target also announced a separate discount for college students, offering $15 off for every $50 spent on household essentials from August 15-21, and a 15% off one-time discount for new Target Circle student members.

title: Lionsgate Acquires Bulk of Weinstein Film Library in Spyglass Deal
summary: Lionsgate has acquired the bulk of the Weinstein Co.'s feature film library from Spyglass Media as part of a broader partnership. This deal includes acclaimed films like "Django Unchained," "Inglourious Basterds," and "The King's Speech" and gives Lionsgate a 20% equity stake in Spyglass, while Spyglass gains a first-look TV deal with Lionsgate. The acquisition significantly expands Lionsgate's content library and provides Spyglass with capital for new projects.

title: Lionsgate Nabs About 200 Films From Spyglass Media in Stake Deal
summary: Lionsgate has acquired a 20 percent stake in Spyglass Media Group, along with approximately 200 film titles from Spyglass's library. This strategic investment aims to bolster Lionsgate's content portfolio, especially for its streaming service Starz, and positions the company for further consolidation in the entertainment industry. Gary Barber will continue to lead Spyglass as chairman and CEO, while both companies look to jointly create new content.

title: Lionsgate Acquires Spyglass Media Stake In Broad Strategic Partnership
summary: Lionsgate has acquired a 20% investment stake in Spyglass Media Group and the vast majority of its 200-title feature film library, forming a strategic content partnership. The agreement includes a multiyear first-look television deal between Lionsgate Television and Spyglass. Gary Barber will continue to lead Spyglass as its Chairman and CEO, with the deal aiming to grow Lionsgate's IP portfolio and global content distribution platform.

title: Self-Driving Startup Aurora Set to Go Public
summary: Aurora Innovation Inc., a self-driving technology startup, has agreed to go public through a merger with Reinvent Technology Partners Y, a special purpose acquisition company. The deal values Aurora at $11 billion and the combined entity at $13 billion, providing about $2.5 billion in cash to commercialize self-driving trucks. The company, led by CEO Chris Urmson, plans to initially focus on the trucking market.

title: Why is Tesla incorporated in Delaware?
summary: This article explains why a disproportionate number of companies, including Tesla, Amazon, and Google, are incorporated in Delaware despite not being headquartered there. Key reasons include flexible corporate law, the efficient Court of Chancery, favorable tax treatment for out-of-state income, and a long-standing state focus on business formation. The article also touches on the challenges this presents for regional data and business coverage.

title: Ford hires general counsel and policy chief
summary: Ford Motor Company has appointed Steven Croley as its new chief policy officer and general counsel, effective July 12. Croley, previously a partner at Latham & Watkins and former general counsel for the US Department of Energy, will report to CEO Jim Farley. He replaces John Mellen, who will retire in September after transitioning his legal responsibilities.

title: GM turns to supplier to build initial EV vans while it readies plant in Canada
summary: General Motors is utilizing German supplier Kuka AG to produce the initial, small batch of its new EV600 commercial vans to accelerate deliveries to customers like Fedex. This atypical move allows GM to meet its late 2021 rollout target, as its Canadian plant designated for EV van production is still manufacturing Chevrolet Equinox SUVs and won't be ready until late 2022. This strategy highlights GM's urgency to enter the growing electric commercial van market.

title: What McDonald’s minimum wage raise says about fast-food franchise future
summary: McDonald's is raising wages for employees at its company-owned restaurants to an average of $15 per hour by 2024, responding to a tight labor market and competition for workers. This move puts pressure on its 95% franchised restaurants to follow suit, with some franchise owners already seeing higher retention rates after implementing similar wage increases. The decision highlights a shift in the fast-food industry towards higher pay, influenced by advocacy groups and a strong economy.

title: Employers offer stipends for babysitting and tutoring to sweeten child-care benefits and win over workers
summary: Companies are increasingly offering enhanced child-care benefits, including backup care, stipends for tutoring and babysitting, and even college counseling, to attract and retain employees, especially working parents. This trend emerged during the Covid-19 pandemic as employers recognized the need to support workers with caregiving responsibilities, aiming to bring women back into the workforce and improve overall employee well-being. These expanded benefits also extend to support for older children and elderly family members, reflecting a broader shift in employer-employee relationships.

title: Oracle CEO Safra Catz underscores Israel support in Jerusalem data center launch
summary: Oracle CEO Safra Catz emphasized Oracle's strong support for Israel during the launch of a new data center in Jerusalem, despite the company losing a major cloud project tender to AWS and Google. Catz, an Israeli-born executive, stated that Oracle's commitment to Israel is unwavering and that employees who disagree with this mission might not be a fit for the company. She also expressed confusion regarding Oracle not being selected for Israel's $1 billion "Nimbus" cloud project.

title: Ford lures top lawyer, senior Amazon employee in latest high-profile hires
summary: Ford Motor Co. has announced two high-profile hires, Steven Croley as chief policy officer and general counsel, and Rebecca Pagani as chief privacy officer. These appointments reflect Ford's commitment to strengthening its government relations, sustainability, legal, and privacy matters, particularly as the company pivots towards electrification. Croley brings extensive regulatory experience from his previous role as general counsel for the U.S. Department of Energy and his time in the Obama administration, while Pagani joins from Amazon with expertise in information security and privacy laws for e-commerce, cloud computing, and AI businesses.

title: Digital Pharmacies Filling Orders Online Go After CVS, Walgreens
summary: Digital pharmacies are emerging as disruptors to traditional brick-and-mortar chains like CVS and Walgreens, promising to save customers time, money, and hassle. Startups like Alto, Capsule, and Medly have collectively raised significant capital, with Amazon's acquisition of PillPack further validating the nascent sector. These companies aim to streamline the prescription fulfillment process, targeting a substantial U.S. industry.

title: LG swings battle for premium TV supremacy
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has accelerated demand for premium TVs, with OLED TV shipments increasing significantly. LG Electronics has seen its share of the premium TV market rise to 28% by Q1, while Samsung's share declined. LG Display's OLED technology is driving this shift, with confidence in OLED's image quality, eye health benefits, and environmental advantages leading to continued market growth and diversification among TV manufacturers.

title: Founder Of Turkish E-Commerce Firm Hepsiburada A Billionaire After IPO
summary: Hanzade Dogan-Boyner, founder of Turkish e-commerce giant Hepsiburada, became a billionaire after the company's U.S. Nasdaq debut. Her stake in the company and other investments brought her net worth to an estimated $1.5 billion, making her one of five women billionaires in Turkey. Hepsiburada, often dubbed Turkey's Amazon, saw its stock rise on its first trading day.

title: Zevia IPO: 5 things to know about the zero-calorie beverage company before it goes public
summary: Zevia PBC, a beverage company specializing in zero-calorie, zero-sugar drinks, has filed to go public. The company, which was the top-selling carbonated soft drink brand on Amazon in 2020, plans to list its class A shares on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker "ZVIA."

title: Shinsegae Acquires eBay Korea In $3 Billion Deal As E-Commerce Booms
summary: South Korean retail giant Shinsegae, through its supermarket affiliate E-Mart, has acquired eBay Korea for $3 billion. This strategic move aims to boost Shinsegae's market share in Korea's rapidly growing e-commerce sector and enhance its delivery and warehouse capabilities. The acquisition positions Shinsegae as a major player against competitors like Naver and Coupang, with plans to invest further in fulfillment services.

title: Predictive maintenance for drones using embedded ML
summary: This article details a project on smart predictive maintenance for drones using embedded machine learning and the QuickLogic QuickFeather development kit. The solution aims to detect minute flaws in drone components, such as loose screws or broken propellers, by analyzing sound data, to prevent catastrophic failures and facilitate efficient autonomous last-mile delivery. The project underscores the importance of transitioning to electric vehicles and proactive maintenance for future drone and UGV-based delivery systems.

title: HPE buys Israeli cloud data co Zerto for $374m
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) has announced its acquisition of Israeli cloud data management and protection company Zerto for $374 million in cash. Zerto's technology, which includes disaster recovery, backup, and data mobility, will be integrated into HPE's GreenLake cloud data services. This acquisition is expected to contribute over $130 million in run-rate revenue to HPE.

title: AT&T to run core 5G network on Microsoft's cloud
summary: AT&T announced it will run core parts of its 5G wireless network on Microsoft's cloud computing platform, marking a significant win for Microsoft in the telecommunications sector. This partnership involves Microsoft purchasing software and intellectual property from AT&T and offering jobs to several hundred AT&T engineers. The move allows AT&T to leverage a larger ecosystem of software developers and will help Microsoft build its Azure for Operators product for telecommunications companies globally.

title: QVC and HSN Streaming Service Launches on Comcast’s Xfinity X1 and Xfinity Flex
summary: QVC and HSN have launched their streaming service on Comcast's Xfinity X1 and Xfinity Flex, making it the first video shopping app on either platform. The service provides X1 and Flex customers access to QVC and HSN's linear channels, on-demand video, and original programming, with plans to make the service shoppable by early 2022. This launch strengthens QVC and HSN's leadership in video commerce and expands their reach to new digital platforms.

title: Rigetti looks to scale up quantum computing with modular processor architecture
summary: Rigetti Computing Inc. is addressing the challenge of scaling quantum computers with a new modular architecture that links smaller qubit collections to function as one processor. This approach aims to overcome the limitations of building larger, single quantum chips that are prone to failure and low manufacturing yields. The company expects to make an 80-qubit system available on its Quantum Cloud Services platform later this year, believing this modular strategy offers the fastest path to practical quantum applications.

title: Southeast Asia’s most valuable company has an edge in the battle of the super-apps: Its gaming business
summary: Sea Limited, Southeast Asia's most valuable company, leverages its highly profitable gaming division, Garena, to fund the rapid expansion of its e-commerce platform, Shopee, and digital financial services arm, SeaMoney. This strategy gives Sea a significant advantage over rivals like Grab and GoTo in the competitive super-app market, allowing it to offer aggressive incentives and capture market share even while operating at an overall loss. The article details Sea's history, its founder's vision for mobile-first services in emerging markets, and the challenges and opportunities facing the company as it seeks sustained profitability and dominance.

title: Warren Buffett's deputy snowballed his retirement account from $70,000 into $264 million. Here are 2 of Ted Weschler's best investments
summary: Warren Buffett's deputy, Ted Weschler, grew his retirement account from $70,000 to $264 million in less than 30 years, according to ProPublica. Two of his most successful investments at his former hedge fund, Peninsula Capital Advisors, were Cogent Communications and WR Grace & Co. These companies saw their stock prices jump 13-fold and 11-fold, respectively, between 2003 and 2011.

title: How Salesforce, Amazon, Google measure climate impact
summary: This article discusses how companies like Salesforce, Amazon, and Google are measuring their climate impact and the challenges involved. It highlights the increasing pressure on companies to demonstrate sustainability efforts through trusted data and metrics, moving beyond just reporting to actively using data to drive decarbonization. The piece also emphasizes the importance of internal communication, incentives, and policymaker involvement in achieving climate goals.

title: Online payment company Payoneer goes public after SPAC merger
summary: Payments provider Payoneer went public on the Nasdaq stock exchange after closing a merger with a special-purpose acquisition company (SPAC) backed by fintech entrepreneur Betsy Cohen. The deal valued the company at about $3.3 billion, and Payoneer expects significant revenue growth in 2021 due to accelerated digital commerce. The company plans to use its new public currency for bolder investments and acquisitions to expand its services.

title: Bank Bucks U.S. Peers, Saying No One Should Return 5 Days a Week
summary: Synchrony Financial (SYF), a major credit card issuer, is embracing a flexible remote work model, opting against a full five-day in-office return for its employees, unlike many of its U.S. banking peers. The company has begun testing its reopening plan with a limited number of employees but is largely committed to remote work and reducing office space. This decision contrasts with banks like Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan Chase, which are pushing for a broader return to the office.

title: How Western Union is fighting back against fintech startups
summary: Western Union, a long-standing player in cross-border payments, is actively combating competition from fintech startups by heavily investing in its digital operations. The company saw significant growth in digital money transfer revenues in 2020 due to the pandemic-driven acceleration towards digital services, and expects revenues to exceed $1 billion in 2021. Western Union is also expanding its offerings beyond payments, including launching a bank account, debit card, and multicurrency accounts in Europe, and modernizing its technology using cloud platforms and AI.

title: Payoneer Is Set to Merge With FTOC, Future Looks Bright
summary: Payoneer is set to go public through a reverse merger with the SPAC FTAC Olympus Acquisition Corp. (FTOC), with common stock expected to trade under "PAYO" on Nasdaq starting June 28. The company, which provides payment services for major firms like Amazon and Google, shows strong financials with expected 2021 revenues of $432 million and a reasonable valuation, making it a potentially attractive investment. Payoneer's business was significantly boosted by the COVID-19 pandemic and the shift to online transactions, with impressive growth reported in Q1 2021, and the company has recently undergone a rebranding effort.

title: Simpson Manufacturing announces the appointment of Kenneth Knight to its board of directors
summary: Simpson Manufacturing Co., Inc. has appointed Kenneth Knight as a non-employee director to its board, where he will also serve on the audit and finance committee. Knight brings extensive experience from roles at Invitae Corporation, Amazon.com, Inc., General Motors Company, and Caterpillar Inc., which is expected to be instrumental for Simpson's growth initiatives. James Andrasick, chair of Simpson’s board, highlighted Knight’s background in industrial manufacturing, M&A, and supply chain management as key assets.

title: PBS FY22 budget increases station dues, spending on content and marketing
summary: PBS's board approved a fiscal year 2022 budget increasing station dues and expenses for content and marketing, totaling $339.1 million. The budget allocates $243.4 million for content and marketing and projects $203.7 million in station dues revenue, with PBS President Paula Kerger emphasizing adapting to the competitive media landscape and focusing on diversity initiatives. This includes a commitment to fund programs by nonfiction filmmakers of color and recruiting a head of diversity, equity, and inclusion.

title: Ford Motor Co. loses chief technology officer Ken Washington to Amazon
summary: Ford's Chief Technology Officer Ken Washington is leaving the automaker to join Amazon as vice president of software engineering. His departure leaves a void in crucial areas like next-generation vehicle electrical architectures and advanced materials, with Jim Buczkowski taking interim responsibility. Washington, who has been CTO since June 2017, played a significant role in Ford's technology strategy, including autonomous vehicle efforts.

title: Ford's chief technology officer to leave company for job at Amazon
summary: Ken Washington, Ford's chief technology officer, is departing the company on July 16 to take a role as vice president of software engineering at Amazon. His departure highlights an ongoing "war for talent" between the auto and tech industries. Jim Buczkowski will serve as interim head of Ford's research and advanced engineering team.

title: Focus: Bezos' 2021 Space Odyssey a risk too far for insurers
authors: Noor Zainab Hussain and Carolyn Cohn
summary: Insurers are hesitant to cover the risks associated with Jeff Bezos's impending space flight and commercial space tourism in general, despite a nearly $500 million market for insuring satellites and unmanned flights. There are currently no legal requirements for operators like Blue Origin to insure passengers for injury or death, and the industry is grappling with whether space travel risks fall under space or aviation insurance lines. However, companies like Global Aerospace have begun receiving inquiries for sub-orbital missions, suggesting this nascent market may evolve substantially in the coming years.

title: Wattpad And Webtoon Merge Studios With $100 Million In Financing
summary: Wattpad and Webtoon have merged their studio divisions to form Wattpad Webtoon Studios, backed by $100 million in financing from their parent company, Naver. The new studio aims to leverage combined IP libraries and creators to produce global fan and data-driven TV shows, films, and books with over 100 projects already in development or production. This strategic move strengthens Naver's global position in IP, digital comics, and web novels.

title: PepsiCo to launch line of premium, non-alcoholic cocktail mixers
summary: PepsiCo is introducing Unmuddled, a new line of premium, non-alcoholic cocktail mixers, in early September. These mixers are made without artificial sweeteners and come in three varieties: Lemon Mint, Fiery Pineapple, and Spiced Mandarin. This launch follows PepsiCo's earlier introduction of Neon Zebra non-alcoholic cocktail mixers in March.

title: Amazon Prime Day is over but deals still exist. Here's how I've gotten $4,700 in rebates and free stuff
summary: This article describes how to find significant discounts on Amazon and other online stores even after major shopping events like Prime Day. The author highlights RebateKey.com as a method to secure rebates and free items without the usual proof-of-purchase hurdles, claiming to have received $4,700 in rebates and free stuff.

title: FTC to review Amazon’s planned $8.45 billion purchase of MGM: report
summary: The Federal Trade Commission will review Amazon.com Inc.’s proposed $8.45 billion acquisition of MGM studios. This review will be conducted under the FTC's new chair, Lina Khan, a known critic of Amazon’s expansion. The deal aims to significantly boost content on Amazon Prime Video, incorporating franchises like James Bond and TV series such as “The Handmaid’s Tale.”

title: Amazon is in talks to buy stake in AI truck-driving startup Plus
authors: Lulu Yilun Chen and Gillian Tan
summary: Amazon.com Inc. has placed an order for 1,000 autonomous driving systems from Plus, an AI truck-driving technology startup. Amazon is also in talks to acquire a stake of up to 20% in Plus, with a warrant enabling them to buy preferred shares at $0.46647 per share, as confirmed by a company filing. This potential deal would give Amazon a significant interest in Plus before its planned merger with Hennessy Capital Investment Corp. V.

title: Amazon Prime Day deals expected to disappoint as costs surge
summary: Amazon Prime Day deals are expected to be less attractive this year due to surging costs, including rising shipping expenses, higher advertising rates, and scarce inventory. Merchants are holding back on deep discounts and inventory, anticipating that supply-chain disruptions will continue through the holiday season. Despite this, online spending in the U.S. during the event is still projected to set a record at $12.2 billion, with Amazon capturing 60%.

title: Amazon in Talks to Buy Stake in AI Truck-Driving Startup Plus
authors: Lulu Yilun Chen and Gillian Tan
summary: Amazon.com Inc. has ordered 1,000 autonomous driving systems from Plus, an AI truck-driving startup, and secured an option to purchase up to a 20% stake in the company. This deal allows Amazon to buy preferred shares at approximately 47 cents per share, potentially valuing Plus at $3.3 billion after its merger with Hennessy Capital Investment Corp. V. Plus, backed by Sequoia Capital China, is developing autonomous technology for longhaul trucking and is expanding its partnerships and operations in the U.S. and China.

title: Will Intuitive Surgical Be a Trillion-Dollar Stock by 2031?
summary: This article analyzes whether Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) can achieve a trillion-dollar market capitalization by 2031. It compares Intuitive's current market cap and growth trajectory to trillion-dollar tech companies, noting its dominance in robotic surgery market but also potential challenges from rivals and revenue growth limitations. Although reaching $1 trillion is deemed unlikely, the author remains optimistic about Intuitive Surgical as a strong long-term investment for healthcare portfolios.

title: Amazon’s Prime Day prompts Walmart, Target, Best Buy deals galore
summary: Amazon's Prime Day is prompting major retailers like Walmart, Target, Kohl's, and Best Buy to launch their own competing sales events. These retailers are strategically timing their discount deals, with many overlapping Prime Day, to attract customers and capture a share of the heightened shopping activity. The article highlights the "retail wars" as these companies aim to capitalize on the sales momentum generated by Amazon's annual event.

title: Realty Income Delivers High Yields and Dependable Dividend Growth
summary: This article analyzes Realty Income (O), a real estate investment trust, highlighting its high yields and consistent dividend growth. The author examines its business model of triple-net leases, tenant concentration, occupancy rates, and FFO trends over the past decade. The piece also discusses potential risks from changing retail landscapes and rising interest rates, while noting the company's strong management, conservative balance sheet, and upcoming acquisition of Vereit (VER).

title: Americans are dining out again. Target wants to lure them to the grocery aisle with deals
summary: Target is adding food and beverages to its Deal Days sales event, aiming to attract consumers back to its grocery aisles even as dining out resumes. This strategic move, which includes discounts and a gift card promotion, marks the first time Target is using the event to promote groceries, a category that significantly boosted its sales during the pandemic. The initiative is a direct response to Amazon Prime Day and reflects a broader effort by grocers like Walmart and Amazon to retain elevated grocery spending amidst shifting consumer habits.

title: Pinnacle Financial Partners relocating headquarters to Nashville Yards location
summary: Pinnacle Financial Partners is relocating its corporate headquarters to the Nashville Yards location in downtown Nashville. The new headquarters will anchor a multi-tenant commercial office building and will also include a 10,000 square foot retail presence and an all-digital office concept within Amazon Nashville. The building is designed to be 34 stories tall with over 650,000 square feet of office space.

title: Amazon and HanesBrands Team Up to File 13 Lawsuits Over the Sale of Counterfeit Champion Products
summary: Amazon and HanesBrands have jointly filed over two dozen lawsuits against sellers on Amazon's marketplace for selling counterfeit Champion products. The lawsuits allege trademark infringement and false designation of origin, seeking monetary damages and injunctive relief to prevent further sales of unauthorized goods. This action is part of a broader effort by Amazon to combat counterfeits and build consumer trust, particularly as issues with seller identity and legislative challenges surrounding the Inform Consumers Act have emerged.

title: Inside a factors-focused model portfolio
summary: Tim Courtney, CIO of Exencial Wealth Advisors, discusses his firm's all-equity model portfolio, highlighting its focus on Dimensional Fund Advisors (DFA) funds for their factor-based weighting towards value, small companies, and profitability, despite recent underperformance. He also addresses portfolio diversification, managing overlap, and specific international fund selections like the DFA International Small Cap Value fund and American Funds EuroPacific Growth fund.

title: Cloud ramp up weighs on Oracle's profit view, shares fall
summary: Oracle Corp's shares fell after the company forecast current-quarter profit below Wall Street estimates, heavily impacted by increased investments in its cloud computing business. The company plans to nearly double its capital spending on the cloud segment to take on rivals like Microsoft and Amazon, even as it sets up more data centers and wins high-profile customers like Zoom Video Communications. Despite beating fourth-quarter revenue and profit estimates, analysts still view Oracle as a niche player in the cloud market compared to leading infrastructure companies.

title: Company bringing 390 jobs to Hazel Park in new 450K-square-foot facility
summary: Mayville Engineering Company (MEC) is establishing its largest facility nationwide, a 450,000-square-foot plant, in Hazel Park, Michigan, at the Tri-County Commerce Center. This move is expected to create 390 well-paying jobs and involves an investment of up to $45 million in new operations, supported by a $2.5 million incentive package from the state. The facility, located on the site of the former Hazel Park Raceway, will significantly expand MEC's manufacturing capacity in Michigan and contribute to the city's tax revenue.

title: Mall owner Washington Prime Group files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, citing COVID challenges
summary: Mall owner Washington Prime Group Inc. filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, citing the COVID-19 pandemic's impact on its operations. The company, which owns 102 shopping centers, has secured $100 million in debtor-in-possession financing to support day-to-day operations during the restructuring process. This move follows a challenging period for many retailers and mall operators, with projections indicating a significant number of malls may close in the coming years.

title: California REIT buys Amazon fulfillment center in Fort Worth
summary: Realty Income Corp., a California-based Real Estate Investment Trust, has purchased a 1.02 million-square-foot Amazon fulfillment center located in Fort Worth, Texas. This acquisition adds to the company's extensive portfolio, which already includes over 800 properties solely in Texas.

title: Walmart's 'Deals for Days' event starts one day ahead of Prime Day
summary: Walmart is launching its "Deals for Days" event on June 20, directly competing with Amazon's Prime Day which runs from June 21-22. This retail showdown includes other major retailers like Target, Kohl's, and Best Buy also hosting their own sales events around the same time. Walmart's spokesperson stated they often hold "Deals for Days" events, offering Black Friday-like savings in-store and online, differing from Amazon's online-only Prime membership requirement.

title: Online Exclusive: Shyft to launch its first EV chassis to meet demands of delivery companies
summary: Shyft Group Inc. is developing its first all-electric chassis platform to meet growing demand from major parcel delivery customers like Amazon, FedEx, and UPS, with production set to begin in mid-2023. The company plans to invest between $50 million and $75 million in the initiative, aiming to produce 500-1,000 units in the first year. This move capitalizes on the increasing industry demand for electric delivery vehicles and builds on Shyft's successful transition to e-commerce truck manufacturing.

title: Kraft Heinz CEO on the Ketchup Shortage
summary: Miguel Patricio, CEO of Kraft Heinz, discusses the ongoing challenges of rising raw material prices, supply chain shocks, and product outages, including the significant ketchup-package shortage. He explains that the shortage is primarily for ketchup pouches due to increased takeout orders during the pandemic, and Kraft Heinz is addressing this by adding eight new production lines to increase capacity by 25% by July. Patricio also touches on broader inflationary pressures in raw materials, particularly edible oils, and how Kraft Heinz is adapting to consumer trends for less processed foods.

title: Coffee chain Starbucks applies for naming rights with US trademark office
summary: Starbucks Corp. has applied with the U.S. trademark office for the right to use its name on a sports stadium or training facility, aiming to potentially join other major companies in sponsoring venues. The application, filed on June 2, seeks approval for "providing stadium and training facilities for sports and entertainment activities" and "promoting business, sports and entertainment events of others." The U.S. Patent and Trademark Office is expected to assign a lawyer to review the application by early September.

title: Palo Alto Networks Enhances Cloud Security Posture Management (CSPM)
summary: Palo Alto Networks has updated its Prisma Cloud solution for Cloud Security Posture Management (CSPM) to help organizations eliminate cybersecurity blind spots and guard against alert fatigue. These enhancements include True Internet Exposure, Visibility-as-Code, Network Data Exfiltration Detection, Anomalous Compute Provisioning Detection, and Customizable Object-Level Scanning for AWS S3. The CSPM market is experiencing significant growth, with revenues projected to reach $9 billion by 2026, driven by the high susceptibility of organizations to security breaches due to cloud misconfigurations.

title: Zoom and Salesforce make quick $23 million profit after IPO of Israeli software vendor Monday.com
summary: Zoom and Salesforce each invested $75 million into Monday.com's IPO, quickly realizing a combined profit of $23 million as the stock jumped 15% on its debut day. This investment strategy is part of a larger trend for Salesforce Ventures, which has yielded significant gains from other IPOs like Snowflake, while Zoom is also beginning to use investments as a new business venture. Both companies are subject to a 180-day lock-up period before they can sell their shares.

title: This Color-Changing Spray Keeps Bathrooms Sparkly Clean
summary: The article highlights Kaboom Cleaner as a highly effective solution for bathroom cleaning, boasting over 11,000 5-star ratings on Amazon. It details different Kaboom products, including a color-changing spray for soap scum and a no-drip foam for mold and mildew, emphasizing their ability to tackle tough stains with the power of OxiClean. The author recommends the products for ease of use and affordability, suggesting Amazon as a convenient purchase option.

title: One of JBG Smith's Amazon point men just left to build National Landing's next big developer
summary: Andy Van Horn, a long-time executive at JBG Smith, has departed the company to join Dweck Properties. He aims to transform Dweck Properties into a major developer, particularly within the National Landing area. This move comes as the region plans for significant development around Amazon's presence.

title: Kroger to hire 10,000 workers across its grocery brands
summary: Kroger announced a hiring event for Thursday to fill 10,000 jobs across its retail, e-commerce, pharmacy, manufacturing, and logistical operations. The company plans to raise its average associate wage to $16 per hour and offers various benefits. This nationwide hybrid hiring event comes as retailers face a competitive labor market, and Kroger seeks to employ staff similar to its pre-pandemic levels after an initial surge in hiring.

title: Microsoft’s Irish subsidiary posted £220bn profit in single year | Tax havens
summary: Microsoft's Irish subsidiary, Microsoft Round Island One, recorded a profit of $315 billion (£222 billion) in a single year, which is nearly three-quarters of Ireland's GDP, despite having no employees other than directors. The company is resident for tax purposes in Bermuda, which has no corporation tax, allowing it to pay no tax on income. This news emerged as G7 finance ministers discussed global minimum corporate tax rates to combat multinational tax avoidance.

title: Pitney Bowes introduces ParcelPoint Smart Lockers
summary: Pitney Bowes has launched ParcelPoint Smart Lockers, an expansion of its parcel locker systems, to address the surging demand for e-commerce and secure package management. These lockers, managed by Pitney Bowes’ SaaS technology, offer remote management and aim to streamline parcel and mail delivery in various settings. The global smart parcel locker market is projected to reach over $1.4 billion by 2027, driven by the exponential growth in parcel volume.

title: Etsy Buys Depop, Fashion Resale Site Popular With Gen Z, for $1.6 Billion
authors: Charity L. Scott and Colin Kellaher
summary: Etsy Inc. announced its agreement to acquire Depop, a privately held fashion marketplace, for $1.63 billion. This acquisition is a significant move into the burgeoning secondhand goods market, giving Etsy access to Depop's younger, fashion-conscious demographic. Depop experienced substantial growth last year, with its gross merchandise sales and revenue more than doubling to approximately $650 million and $70 million, respectively.

title: Etsy is acquiring UK-based social selling site Depop for $1.625B in a mostly cash deal
summary: Etsy is acquiring UK-based social selling site Depop for $1.625 billion in a mostly cash deal, marking Etsy's largest acquisition to date. This move is significant for e-commerce, especially in targeting younger consumers, as 90% of Depop's 21 million users are under 26. The acquisition aims to broaden Etsy's reach to millennial and Gen Z shoppers and strengthen its presence in the U.S. and U.K. markets.

title: KKR, CD&R take data analytics firm Cloudera private for $4.7 bln
summary: Private equity firms Clayton Dubilier & Rice LLC (CD&R) and KKR & Co (KKR.N) are taking cloud-based data analytics company Cloudera Inc (CLDR.N) private for $4.7 billion. Cloudera's shares jumped 23.9% following the announcement, nearing the offer price of $16 per share. The move is intended to help Cloudera transition more smoothly into hybrid cloud solutions without the pressure of quarterly reporting.

title: KKR, CD&R Strike $5.3 Billion Deal to Buy Cloudera
summary: Private-equity firms KKR & Co. and Clayton Dubilier & Rice LLC have agreed to acquire software company Cloudera Inc. for approximately $5.3 billion, taking the company private. The deal values Cloudera at $16 per share, representing a 24% premium over its closing price on the preceding Friday. Cloudera, founded by engineers from major tech companies, struggled to adapt to the public cloud market, facing stiff competition from larger firms.

title: Fifth Third Bank warns of text scams about online banking
summary: Fifth Third Bank is warning customers about text message scams claiming a "temporary hold" has been placed on their online banking accounts. These texts are fraudulent, and the bank advises caution against clicking links or sharing personal information. Customers should be suspicious of urgent requests for account numbers or Social Security numbers and can call Fifth Third directly if unsure about a message's legitimacy.

title: How Nvidia plans to own the data center with AI
summary: Nvidia aims to revolutionize enterprise computing by making data centers run 10 times faster at one-tenth the cost, leveraging its strong position in AI architectures. The company plans to disrupt Intel's x86 dominance through Arm-based architectures, integrated chip designs, and a compelling software consumption model. The article highlights Nvidia's strategic moves, financial standing, and the potential impact of its proposed acquisition of Arm Ltd. on the data center market.

title: Coinbase crypto partner Circle raises $440 million from Fidelity and others
summary: Cryptocurrency startup Circle, a Coinbase partner, has successfully raised $440 million in new funding from investors including Fidelity and FTX. This funding round highlights the growing investor appetite for crypto companies, coinciding with Coinbase's market debut and Circle's own plans to go public via a SPAC at a $4 billion valuation. Circle is increasingly focusing on its USD Coin (USDC) stablecoin, which has seen significant growth and adoption for digital payments.

title: How Vimeo went from CollegeHumor side project to a multibillion-dollar company
summary: Vimeo, once a side project of CollegeHumor, has grown into a multibillion-dollar public software company. Initially acquired by IAC almost by accident, Vimeo pivoted from being a YouTube competitor to building video software for businesses under the leadership of Anjali Sud. The company recently went public with over 200 million users and 1.6 million paying subscribers, generating substantial revenue.

title: Amazon shareholder meeting: Push to put an hourly worker on board
summary: Labour activists are pushing for an hourly worker to join Amazon's board of directors at its shareholder meeting, following a failed union drive. The proposal, backed by Oxfam America and recommended by proxy adviser ISS, aims to elevate employee concerns amidst allegations of monopolistic practices and environmental racism. However, Amazon's board opposes the resolution, and some proxy advisers are concerned about board independence.

title: Hedge Fund and Insider Trading News: Carl Icahn, Warren Buffett, Bill Ackman, Ray Dalio, Elliott Management, Assurant Inc. (AIZ), Innoviva Inc (INVA), and More
summary: This article covers recent news in the hedge fund and insider trading world, featuring prominent investors like Carl Icahn, Bill Ackman, and Elliott Management. Key topics include Carl Icahn's activism, Bill Ackman's SPAC deal and market outlook, Elliott Management's strategy regarding GlaxoSmithKline, and Amazon's acquisition of MGM bolstering hedge fund profits. The article also touches on increasing data demands driving hedge fund operational costs and hedge fund assets reaching a new high of over $4 trillion.

title: Amazon buys MGM as D.C. suit charges its monopolistic practices violate antitrust laws
summary: Amazon announced its acquisition of MGM for $8.5 billion, capitalizing on the film industry's struggles. This comes as Washington D.C. Attorney General Karl Racine filed an antitrust suit against Amazon, alleging that its contractual terms force third-party sellers to offer products at lower prices on Amazon, thereby harming both sellers and customers through inflated fees and prices. The lawsuit highlights Amazon's significant control over online retail and questions the monopolistic practices of platform companies.

title: Microsoft teams up with Accenture and Goldman Sachs to create energy efficient software
summary: Microsoft, Accenture, and Goldman Sachs, along with other organizations, are forming the Green Software Foundation to develop and share methods for creating software that produces fewer carbon emissions in data centers. Data centers currently account for about 1% of global electricity demand, projected to rise significantly, prompting the need for "green software engineering" skills. The foundation aims to build tools, establish standards for measuring software's climate impact, and provide training for engineers.

title: Oracle launches Arm-based cloud computing service using Ampere chips
summary: Oracle Corp has launched a new cloud computing service that utilizes Arm-based data center chips from Ampere Computing, becoming the second major cloud provider after Amazon Web Services to offer such a service. This move aims to provide customers with more value and choice, challenging the long-standing dominance of Intel and AMD in the cloud chip market. Oracle is also promoting initiatives to expand software compatibility with Arm chips.

title: Oracle debuts its first Arm-based cloud instances
summary: Oracle has launched its first Arm-based cloud instances, OCI Ampere A1 Compute, offering customers more flexibility and high performance at lower costs for general-purpose and cloud-native workloads. This move signifies Oracle's increased investment in the Arm ecosystem, providing a compelling alternative to x86-based instances and competing with rival cloud providers by offering attractive pricing and scaling options. The company is also expanding developer resources and tools to encourage Arm-based application development on its cloud platform, including free tier offerings and a new development stack.

title: The Curious Case of a Toys ‘R’ Us Killer
summary: This article traces the unexpected connection between Vornado Realty, a prominent real estate firm, and the demise of Toys 'R' Us, highlighting Vornado's own twisting corporate history. It reveals how Vornado, originally an appliance manufacturer and then a discount retailer (Two Guys), transformed into a real estate giant by leveraging its suburban land holdings. The piece argues that Vornado's trajectory and engagement with Toys 'R' Us exemplify broader, long-term trends of offshoring and financialization within the American economy.

title: P&G Earns Seventh Straight Gartner Supply Chain Mastery Award
summary: P&G has received its seventh consecutive Gartner Supply Chain Mastery Award, an achievement that highlights its long-term excellence in supply chain management. This recognition comes despite the extreme disruptions caused by the pandemic, which tested P&G's supply chain significantly. P&G is one of only five companies, including Apple, Amazon, McDonald’s, and Unilever, to be recognized in the elite "Master" category, which acknowledges consistent top performance over many years.

title: Amazon shutting down Prime Now, moving two-hour delivery to Amazon app
summary: Amazon is discontinuing its standalone Prime Now app, integrating its two-hour delivery services for essential goods and groceries directly into the main Amazon app and website. This move aims to streamline the shopping experience for customers by offering all of Amazon's services from a single platform. The integration will allow users to shop from Whole Foods and other local stores with expedited delivery.

title: Sprouts accelerates efforts to stand out with unique products
summary: Sprouts Farmers Market is intensifying its focus on selling unique, wellness-oriented products not found at other retailers, aiming to differentiate itself and attract "health enthusiasts." CEO Jack Sinclair stated that the company is positioning itself as a specialty food business rather than a conventional grocer, which allows it to thrive in its e-commerce operations with higher-margin, attribute-based products. This strategy has led to a significant portion of its inventory being unique compared to competitors, and Sprouts sees opportunities as other retailers like Whole Foods diversify into more conventional offerings.

title: JPMorgan Chase Launches In-House Healthcare Company, Morgan Health
summary: JPMorgan Chase has launched its own healthcare company, Morgan Health, after the dissolution of its joint venture with Amazon and Berkshire Hathaway. The new unit will focus on improving medical care for the banking giant's 165,000 employees and their families, with an initial investment of $250 million earmarked for promising healthcare solutions. JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon stated the goal is to address long-standing healthcare issues and achieve significant improvements.

title: JPMorgan launching business arm to address cost, quality of employer healthcare
summary: JPMorgan Chase is launching a new business arm called Morgan Health to address the cost and quality of employer-sponsored healthcare, building on lessons learned from its dissolved Haven venture with Amazon and Berkshire Hathaway. JPMorgan plans to invest $250 million in healthcare solutions, initially focusing on its own employees before aiming to serve as a model for other employers. Morgan Health will partner with healthcare organizations, including CVS Health, to enhance care options and boost health equity.

title: The Business Ethics Leadership Alliance Welcomes New Members, Amazon, Regeneron Pharmaceuticals, and More While Recognizing Companies and Leaders With Exceptional Impact
summary: The Business Ethics Leadership Alliance (BELA) announced new member companies, including Amazon and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals, significantly expanding its community to over 325 organizations. Ethisphere, BELA's founder, also recognized seven companies and individual leaders with BELA Impact Awards for their exceptional commitment to community engagement, growth, and transformation in ethical business practices. The awards highlight crucial contributions to the compliance and ethics profession amidst ongoing global challenges.

title: Polen Focus Growth Fund Purchased Amazon.com (AMZN), Should You Do the Same?
summary: Polen Capital's "Polen Focus Growth" fund purchased Amazon.com (AMZN) in February 2021, making it 5% of their portfolio, based on increased visibility into the company's free cash flow margins and future earnings growth from AWS and Advertising. The fund, which returned 1.81% in Q1 2021, highlighted Amazon's evolving profit drivers from e-commerce to higher-margin services. Despite past concerns about Amazon's fit with their guardrails, Polen Capital now believes these high-margin segments could drive over 30% annual earnings growth for the next five years.

title: NHL, Amazon Web Services to debut advanced stats during playoffs
summary: The NHL and Amazon Web Services (AWS) announced the debut of two new advanced analytics, "shot analytics" and "save analytics," during the 2021 Stanley Cup Playoffs. These stats will be displayed as on-screen graphics and data visualizations, providing fans with deeper insights into player and team performance. Leveraging historical NHL data and real-time game activity, these analytics aim to enhance the broadcast viewing experience and offer new perspectives for fans, players, coaches, and broadcasters.

title: JPMorgan Is America’s Largest Company In 2021, But Amazon Is Rising In The Ranks
summary: Despite a pandemic, America's largest companies grew significantly in 2021, with JPMorgan Chase maintaining its position as the largest for the third consecutive year. Meanwhile, Amazon climbed into the top five, reflecting the growing importance of e-commerce, while traditional giants like AT&T and ExxonMobil saw significant drops in rankings. This year's Global 2000 ranking illustrates the resilience and shifts within the U.S. corporate landscape amidst economic volatility.

title: Amazon borrows $18.5 billion it doesn’t need in new debt sale
summary: Amazon.com Inc. issued $18.5 billion in new debt, its largest bond sale ever, despite holding $73 billion in cash and cash equivalents. The company is taking advantage of historically low borrowing costs to refinance debt, buy back stock, and fund general corporate purposes, including potential acquisitions and green projects. This move highlights a trend among U.S. investment-grade firms to secure cheap financing for growth and strategic initiatives as the economy rebounds.

title: Iron Mountain joins The Climate Pledge
summary: Iron Mountain has joined The Climate Pledge, committing to achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2040, a decade ahead of the Paris Agreement's goal. As an information and asset management business, Iron Mountain has already significantly reduced its greenhouse gas emissions and aims for 100% clean power generation for its data centers. This move signifies its dedication to environmental impact reduction and aligns with over 100 other companies in the pledge.

title: Jessica Alba's Honest Co. surges in Nasdaq debut
summary: Jessica Alba's eco-friendly personal care brand, Honest Co. (HNST), saw its shares surge 44% in its Nasdaq debut, closing at $23 per share and giving the company a market value of about $2.1 billion. CEO Nick Vlahos viewed the successful IPO as validation of the company's mission-driven strategy focused on clean, sustainable, and socially responsible products. Despite its growth in sales to over $300 million in 2020 and narrowing net losses, the company has not yet turned a profit and has previously faced controversial lawsuits regarding its product labeling.

title: Drivers don't work for Amazon but company has lots of rules for them
summary: Amazon exerts significant control over its Delivery Service Partners (DSPs) and their drivers, despite not directly employing them, dictating everything from personal grooming to social media posts. This "fissured" labor model helps Amazon avoid costs and liabilities, but legal experts warn it could lead to "joint employer" or "vicarious liability" claims, especially under closer scrutiny in the Biden administration. The company faces ongoing lawsuits regarding wage theft and accountability for accidents, highlighting the controversial nature of its delivery operations.

title: Jessica Alba’s Honest Co. IPO soars on $1.4 billion valuation
summary: Jessica Alba's The Honest Company Inc. made its public debut, with its IPO raising over $412 million and valuing the company at $1.4 billion. The stock, trading under the ticker HNST, saw a significant pop of over 40% on its first day. The wellness brand, founded in 2011, offers clean beauty, baby products, and household items, and has expanded its retail presence.

title: Google to power Virginia data centers with 24/7 clean energy from AES
summary: AES has signed a 10-year agreement to exclusively supply 24/7 clean energy to three Google data centers in Virginia, utilizing a 500-MW portfolio of resources. This partnership aims to decarbonize Google's operations in the state and sets a precedent for other companies seeking to eliminate carbon from their energy supply. The AES portfolio will require approximately $600 million for its clean energy projects.
